inputColumn.comments: Site Identifier. This field can be used to select the aggregations by sub-customer. This identifier must be used to retrieve the site name provided in configuration (this allows to immediately take into account a renaming of site). Example: 1934.

Description for customer statistics: Element concerned by these aggregations. This field can be empty (which means that the aggregations are concerning the whole site), or contain a value. Depending on the context, this value can be a name (ex: name of OPM), an identifier (ex: destination siteId). Description for global statistics (and for all the BTG meta-customers): This field is always empty (no site to site statistics)

Direction of traffic, used only to describe the traffic by site (files *SiteVolumes.txt). This field can be empty (to represent any direction). The others possible values are "In" (Incoming traffic) or "Out" (Outgoing traffic).

Description for customer statistics: Subset of traffic identified by an "AFDB call type" (ex: "offNet"). This field can be empty. In this case, the aggregations are concerning the total traffic (always provided if we have measurements for this period) When the AFDB configuration doesn't allow identifying a traffic subset, the default value of this field is the GK CDR call type. Description for global statistics (and for all the BTG meta-customers): This field is always empty (no distinction of traffic subset)

Description for customer statistics: Name of telephony zone (ex: "CHINA-GUANGDONG"). This field can be empty (which means that the aggregation is done without distinction of telephony zone). Description for global statistics (and for all the BTG meta-customers): This field is always empty (no distinction of telephony zone).
Prefix of phone number. This field can be empty
Number of phone calls that resulted in communication between the caller and the called party.
Number of phone calls said to be "accepted" (called party busy, called party does not answer, ...)
Number of phone calls that have failed.
